entry.title: Combined summary - Consensus protocol immutability is a feature
entry.summary: The Bitcoin community is currently engaged in a discussion around how to balance maintaining network stability and adapting to changing user needs through protocol changes. The conversation centers on the use of softforks versus hardforks for certain changes to the Bitcoin protocol. Softforks have been used in the past to make significant changes such as SegWit, but there are limitations to what can be changed through a softfork, particularly regarding the block header format and how proof-of-work is computed from it.Some proposals have been made to address these limitations, such as including both SHA-256 and SHA-3 hashes in the same place in the block header format. Additionally, changes to the Merkle Tree could be made by requiring miners to embed a commitment to the SHA3-Merkle-Tree on the coinbase of the "original" block format. However, any hardforks would require even more work and face a higher hurdle of being a hardfork. Therefore, anyone considering a hardfork must be prepared to work on it for several years before it is considered seriously.Developers are advised to focus on making improvements that do not involve changing the consensus protocol, as otherwise, they would be working on an altcoin which is off-topic in the discussion forum. While some argue that Bitcoin's resistance to consensus changes is a feature that makes it resistant to being coopted and corrupted, others believe that such changes are necessary for continuous improvement. The bitcoin-dev mailing list, hosted by the Linux Foundation, has been discussing the potential for using softforks instead of hardforks for certain changes to the Bitcoin protocol. User ZmnSCPxj argues that the space of possible softforks is wider than expected, and SegWit serves as proof that massive changes can be made with a softfork. Taproot's implementation and deployment have taken a long time due to controversy surrounding the activation code.Despite limitations, the flexibility of the coinbase allows for new commitments to be added to new Merkle Trees, which can annotate transactions with additional information invisible to unupgraded nodes. The email thread provides valuable insights into the ongoing discussions around the Bitcoin protocol and its potential updates, and interested individuals can join the conversation through the provided link to the mailing list's signup page. Additionally, an individual has maintained a potential "emergency" branch to add some kind of post-quantum signature scheme to Bitcoin in case of a quantum break.
